thread.title: Goe: With the loss to Washington State, Oregon's season takes a sharp turn for the worst
thread.title_full: Goe: With the loss to Washington State, Oregon's season takes a sharp turn for the worst | OregonLive.com

author: Ken Goe | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Goe: With the loss to Washington State, Oregon's season takes a sharp turn for the worst
text:
EUGENE – Washington State's celebration began on the field, and was still rocking 20 minutes later in the Cougars' locker room at the east end of Autzen Stadium.
The Cougars obviously thought beating Oregon was a major accomplishment.
It might not seem that way for long.
WSU's 45-38 victory over Oregon Saturday was the Ducks' second consecutive loss at home and their third overall this season.
These aren't Marcus Mariota's Ducks. This isn't Chip Kelly's offense. T.J. Ward and Ifo Ekpre-Olomu aren't patrolling the UO secondary.
This is beginning to look like a long season in Eugene, made more dreary by the Ducks' recent success.
"They've had a great thing going for the past however long it's been," WSU linebacker Jeremiah Allison said. "They've been one of the best teams in the country."
No more. The Ducks (3-3) are .500 at the regular season's halfway point, and the easy part of the schedule is in the rearview mirror.
Washington, fresh from a Thursday upset of USC, waits next week in Seattle. Then comes an Arizona State, Cal, Stanford and USC minefield.
The scoreboard showed WSU won in double-overtime, but the statistical story is damning.
The Cougars finished with 31 first downs to Oregon's 18, had 505 yards passing to Oregon's 123 and rolled up 641 yards total offense.
The Ducks had a 10-point lead with 8:20 play and couldn't hold it.
Asked how he felt at the 8:20 mark, WSU coach Mike Leach said: "I was kind of concerned. I figured we ought to be 10 up. ...
"We moved the ball pretty much the whole game. All of a sudden there would be mishap."
Until the game was on the line. Then the Cougars finished like Muhammad Ali.
"We outpunched them at the end," Leach said.
It happened at Autzen, in front of 57,775 fans imploring the Ducks to land the last blow.
Two weeks ago, the Ducks lost to Utah, which might be the best team in the conference. This time they lost to the team picked to finish fifth in the Pac-12 North.
Remember, Washington State (3-2) began the season by face-planting at home against Portland State.
No knock on PSU, which is 4-1 and blew out North Texas on Saturday. The Vikings look like they might be in the top echelon of the Big Sky Conference.
But when a Pac-12 team loses at home to an FCS school, it's a sure sign of trouble.
Mark Helfrich press conference after 45-38 OT loss to WSU Helfrich talked about missing chances to finish the game in regulation and about the quarterback rotation.
Speaking of trouble, who could have anticipated the way the bottom has dropped out at Oregon?
At the moment, Oregon's offense is all about top-shelf running backs Royce Freeman and Taj Griffin. They combined for 345 yards rushing, well over half of the UO offense.
The Ducks don't throw it well enough to force a good defense to play them honestly.
That problem could ease when – or, if – quarterback Vernon Adams recovers from a fractured index finger on his passing hand.
But it's hard to understand how this program doesn't have another guy on the depth chart who can execute the offense.
Of course, Adams was a one-season bandage from the start.
And Adams doesn't play defense. The theory that Oregon's young secondary would improve with experience now looks fatally flawed.
If Oregon's defensive backs are getting better, it's not happening fast enough. Not with what is waiting in the second half of the season.
"There is nobody on that team over there that 15 teams weren't recruiting," Leach said. "They all had 15 offers or better. They're good players."
Scott Frost talks about QB rotation after loss to WSU Frost also talked about one particular play and about play calling, especially near the end of regulation.
If true, Oregon has too many players who were massively overrated. Or the good players they have aren't performing to their ability level.
Freeman and Griffin could suit up for anyone. The Ducks have proven receivers, if they had a quarterback who could execute the passing game.
Charles Nelson was all over the field on both sides of the ball.
But after that, on this night, Washington State looked better.
Which is why the Cougars could celebrate, and why Oregon's fans could be in for a very depressing second half of the season.
-- Ken Goe
kgoe@oregonian.com
503-221-8040 | @KenGoe
